awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Developing a Pivoting-sliding Elliptical Machine for Knee Injury Prevention/Rehabilitation
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project develops a new exercise device for neuromuscular training about the minor/secondary axes to reduce and prevent lower-limb injuries. Considering joints in the lower-limb including knee and ankle are free to flex-extend but with much more limited motions about the minor/secondary axes (leg twisting and side sway at the knee and ankle twisting and side sway), injuries often occur with excessive minor/secondary axis loadings. However, there is a lack of convenient and effective devices that can be used to train minor/secondary-axis neuromuscular control of human lower-limb during functional major-axis stepping/running movements. This project will address the strong exercise and clinical needs and develop a unique minor/secondary-axis exercising device to help subjects improve minor/secondary-axis neuromuscular control and rehabilitate/prevent knee/ankle injuries associated with excessive minor/secondary-axes loadings. Practically, this minor/secondary-axis exercising mechanism can be implemented with many existing exercise machines (elliptical machine, stepper, stair climber, bicycles, and leg press machines) for minor/secondary-axis training. As a powerful clinical evaluation tool, this system can also provide quantitative outcome evaluation.

  The broader impact/commercial potential of this project includes the novel training modality, widely used exercise platforms, and focused training protocol.  The proposed unique minor/secondary-axis neuromuscular training device may directly help reduce various lower limb injuries.  Furthermore, it may benefit multiple joints in the human lower (and potentially upper in a similar way) limbs and it may benefit individuals with minor/secondary-axis impairments in neurological disorders as well as musculoskeletal injuries. Similarly, the widely occurring knee osteoarthritis and leading cause of disability is closely associated with unbalanced/improper frontal plane loadings. The proposed minor/secondary-axis training device will provide a general platform and training strategy to help people better deal with potentially injurious off-axis loadings of the whole lower limbs with quantitative outcome evaluations. Practically, the minor/secondary-axis training can be implemented on various common exercise equipment including elliptical machines, steppers, stair climbers, and bicycles. The minor/secondary-axis training device can be used in hospitals/clinics for post-surgery/injury rehabilitation, and in gym and home settings for injury prevention training as well as rehabilitation. People of various ages and at various sports/activity levels can be trained to better prepare for potentially injurious off-axis loadings and avoid potential injuries.

por.por_cntn:
As the final milestone of this project, a unique Off-Axis training system has been fully developed and many researchers have been utilizing it as a powerful lower-limb research platform in several research institute.

The knee is the most frequently injured body structure, with ACL injuries and patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS) as the most frequent problems in sports and recreational activities. Considering the knee is free to flex-extend but with much more limited motions about the off-axes (tibial rotation and abduction/adduction), injuries often occur with excessive off-axis loadings. However, to our knowledge, there is a lack of convenient and effective devices/equipment that can be used to train off-axis neuromuscular control in athletes’ and non-athletes’ knees in combination with functional major-axis stepping/running/cycling movements.

This project has addressed the issues and developed a unique pivoting-sliding system to help subjects improve off-axis neuromuscular control. The proposed pivoting-sliding mechanism can provide off-axis training for rehabilitation/prevention of knee and ankle injuries, which are associated with excessive off-axes loadings at the joints. Practically, this pivoting and sliding mechanism can be implemented with many existing exercise machines (elliptical machine, stepper, stair climber, and bicycle exerciser) for off-axis training. As a powerful clinical evaluation tool, this system can benefit outcome evaluation in knee injury prevention and rehabilitation.

The invented unique neuromuscular training system on the pivoting-sliding mechanism has significant potential for post-injury/surgery rehabilitation and injury prevention/reduction of the knee such as ACL injuries and patellofemoral pain syndrome. Furthermore, it can be used for other joints/DOFs (degrees of freedom) in the lower limb as well such as Individuals with neurological disorders such as stroke and cerebral palsy, since excessive loadings about these off-axes are associated with injuries. Similarly, the widely occurring knee osteoarthritis (OA) is regarded as closely associated with unbalanced/improper off-axis loadings in the frontal plane. In general, the proposed development will provide a device platform and training strategy to help people better deal with potentially injurious off-axis loadings/movements of the whole lower limbs with quantitative outcome evaluations.

Our invention will help people better deal with potentially injurious off-axis loadings/movements of the lower limbs with quantitative outcome evaluations. The off-axis training system can be used in hospitals/clinical centers for post-surgery/injury rehabilitation, and in gym and home settings for injury prevention training. High school/college students can be taught and trained to better prepare for injurious off-axis loadings. Practically, its virtual reality interface motivates the subjects to achieve more effective training.
